channel.title: Bitmap Help
channel.description:
hi i dont actually need to know what bitmaps are or how to use them its that when i put a bitmap into scar using picture to string i get a very small code i dont know why
ex. this is the bitmap i used in scar [IMG]http://img462.imageshack.us/img462/2117/m5iz.png[/img]
and this is the code i got
[code] M := BitmapFromString(17, 17, 'z78DA33301805D4016E488012358' + '3CD164C73F0CB52620B7E40AD1023466434F6476D190543050000' + '98DD5DF0');[/code] small hunh?
the size of the picture is 17x17 and is 24 bit-depth
i need help plz help me

item.title: Bitmap Help
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

For the post before this one, this might help you.

function FindDeformedBitmapToleranceRotationIn(bitmap: Integer; var x, y: Integer; x1, y1, x2, y2: Integer; tolerance: Integer; Range: Integer; var accuracy: Extended; AngleIntervals: Extended; StartAngle, MaxAngle: Extended; var angle: Extended): Boolean; - Works similar to FindDeformedBitmapToleranceIn but allows searching for rotated bitmaps as well. Basically it rotates bitmap, searches in target image, then rotates again, searches again. AngleIntervals specifies by how much it rotates every time, StartAndge specifies initial rotation angle, MaxAngle specifies how far it rotates and angle returns angle of found image. All angles are specified in radians (Pi = 180˚) Example: FindDeformedBitmapToleranceRotationIn(minimaptree, x, y, 582, 37, 700, 117, 170, 0, acc, PI/10, 0, 2*PI, angle);

Edit: Unless I had a very good reason, I wouldn’t use this approach for this.

Read full topic

item.title: Bitmap Help
item.dc:creator: @aboruck aboruck
item.description:
@aboruck wrote:

Hello…I am a very new scripter and I am trying to use bitmaps instead of colour picking to find monks on an autofighter. Since the monks “move” does that mean I ahve to get coding from like every angle possible for them to be recognised? Anyways just a n00b scripter looking for soem help!

Abor

Read full topic

item.title: Bitmap Help
item.dc:creator: @iruleatants iruleatants
item.description:
@iruleatants wrote:

heres what i say

if you get a small bit map and it work, does it really matter?

Read full topic

item.title: Bitmap Help
item.dc:creator: @Arkanor Arkanor
item.description:
@Arkanor wrote:

-Chaos-:

i didnt take it from a charset i took it from a screenshot i took from runescape

I meant that it appeared that you were creating a charset and were displaying one of your characters.

arent bitmaps only supposed to have 2 colors in it?

Um… only if you’re a fan of FindBitmapMaskTolerance. Or if you’re making a charset. Otherwise, colors are perfectly fine. Where’d you get the idea that all bitmaps must be bichromatic.

does the small code still have the same effect as the bigger one?

Only if you use FindBitmapMaskTolerance. Otherwise, if I remember correctly, it is useless.

Read full topic

item.title: Bitmap Help
item.dc:creator: @Chaos -Chaos-
item.description:
@Chaos wrote:

Arkanor:

That’s a bichromatic bitmap. People typically use those to make charsets (and it appears that you have an M from a charset). It’s very small because there are only two colors in it, black and white.

i didnt take it from a charset i took it from a screenshot i took from runescape and arent bitmaps only supposed to have 2 colors in it?

and does the small code still have the same effect as the bigger one?

Read full topic

item.title: Bitmap Help
item.dc:creator: @KyleGut3 KyleGut3
item.description:
@KyleGut3 wrote:

Small is good… makes your code look more neat [hated the huge string I got before I realized I could crop it more].

Read full topic

@Arkanor wrote:

That’s a bichromatic bitmap. People typically use those to make charsets (and it appears that you have an M from a charset). It’s very small because there are only two colors in it, black and white.
